channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anger Spreads With 5 Attacks on Israelis
item.description: Palestinians had stabbed or attempted to stab five Israelis, most of them members of the security forces, according to the police and the military.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After Strong Start in Canada Campaign, New Democrats Appear to Fade
item.description: As Monday’s vote approaches, the prospect that Tom Mulcair will lead the New Democrats, a left-of-center party, to power is diminishing.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Mulcair, leader of the New Democratic Party, during a campaign stop this month at Schwartz's, a popular Montreal deli.

item.title: Guinea’s President Is Re-elected
item.description: President Alpha Condé received enough votes to avoid a runoff, the election commission said, but his opponents say they will not recognize the results.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Britain to Put Commerce With China First in President Xi Jinping’s State Visit
item.description: The British government has been criticized by many for putting commercial interests ahead of other concerns, including human rights, cybersecurity and China’s growing territorial ambitions.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A worker decorating a street in London’s Chinatown on Friday in preparation for the coming visit by President Xi Jinping of China.

item.title: As Conflicts Flare Up, Leaders Fan Sectarian Flames in Middle East
item.description: National and religious leaders are using sectarian appeals to mobilize their followers — transforming political conflicts into religious struggles and making the region’s bloodshed harder to contain, scholars and analysts say.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Sunni Muslim clerics gathered at an anti-Russia protest in front of the Russian Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hungary Closes Border, Changing Refugees’ Path
item.description: Hundreds of refugees, mostly from Syria, were diverted to Slovenia instead of through Hungary, which closed its border, once a main transit route.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Migrants on Saturday at a train station in Cakovec, Croatia, where they will be taken to Slovenia by bus and train. Refugees were diverted there after Hungry closed its border.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: British Museum’s Director Follows a Fascination to Germany
item.description: Neil MacGregor will leave his post in Britain to help shape one of Germany’s most audacious cultural projects, the Humboldt Forum.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I began in and with the language, and it keeps going back to language.”

item.title: Mayor de Blasio, Visiting Jerusalem, Hears From All Sides of Region’s Conflict
item.description: On his first trip to the Middle East since being elected, Mayor Bill de Blasio was careful in his remarks on recent violence in the region, saying that his visit coincided with “a very painful reality.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio with children from a mixed Jewish-Arab school in Beit Shemesh, Israel, on Saturday.

item.title: Alvin P. Adams Jr., Ambassador Who Helped Haiti Pursue Democracy, Dies at 73
item.description: Mr. Adams, a three-time ambassador, persuaded a Haitian military ruler in 1990 to abdicate. That move paved the way for Haiti’s first freely elected president.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Alvin P. Adams Jr. with Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was the first freely elected Haitian president, in Port-au-Prince in 1991.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: A Rapist’s Nightmare
item.description: A girl in India resists threats and bribes to pursue the upper-caste men she says gang-raped her.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Like many girls in her village in India, Bitiya was raped and expected to remain silent. But, supported by her family, she has fought to see the four upper-caste men who attacked her prosecuted.

item.title: In Unpredictable Canadian Elections, Plurality Is More Important Than Popularity
item.description: Each of the three big parties has led in one poll or another, but the country’s robust, dizzying political culture puts the race well beyond the reach of trustworthy handicapping.
item.dc:creator: JIM DWYER
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Mulcair of the New Democratic Party. Each of Canada's three big parties has led in one poll or another, but the country’s robust, dizzying political culture and first-past-the-post-system of simple plurality make it hard to predict an outcome.

item.title: East Jerusalem, Bubbling Over With Despair
item.description: East Jerusalem, long the emotional heart of Palestinian life, is now the fiery soul of its discontent: Its residents feel neglected by the Israeli government and the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Mourners carry the body of Ehab Hanani, 21, a Palestinian who was killed in a clash with Israeli troops on Friday, during his funeral in Beit Furik in the West Bank.

item.title: ‘El Chapo’ Fled as Security Forces Closed In, Mexico Officials Say
item.description: Security forces hunting for the escaped drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera tracked him to a hide-out in Mexico’s remote northwestern mountains, but he fled as they approached, injuring his leg and his face, Mexican officials said late Friday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: News Analysis: Now the Hardest Part: Making the Iran Deal Work
item.description: As the deal takes effect, Iran insists it can quickly complete a complex nuclear dismantlement, but Iran and the United States each fear the possibility of cheating and disagreement.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: With Anti-Muslim Campaign, Canada Has Its Trump Moment
item.description: Used to the moral high ground, Canadians are watching their own politics getting dragged into divisive immigrant-bashing.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN PATRIQUIN
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press

item.title: Fearing Election Losses, Taiwan’s Governing Party Drops Its Presidential Candidate
item.description: The Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party, chose Eric Chu on Saturday as its new nominee, replacing Hung Hsiu-chu, who has trailed badly in the polls.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Eric Chu, the Kuomintang's chairman, is now the party's presidential nominee.

item.title: With Return of Prize, India’s Literary Stars Protest Rising Intolerance
item.description: A breakdown, which the authors say has been allowed to fester under the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, inspires a writers’ revolt.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
item.media:description: Indian activists, seeking an investigation into the beating death of a Muslim man, shouted slogans against Prime Minister Narendra Modi during a protest in New Delhi on Oct. 6.

item.title: India Writers Return Awards to Protest Government Silence on Violence
item.description: The revolt now confronts Prime Minister Narendra Modi with a critical test of his vaunted ability to shape the public narrative of his administration.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Sudheendra Kulkarn, a former senior Indian offical, left, said that far-right Hindu nationalists poured black paint on his face to protest the launch of a book by Khurshid Mahmud Kasuri, right, a former Pakistani foreign minister.

item.title: World Briefing: Burkina Faso: New Charges in Coup
item.description: The general who took power after last month’s coup in Burkina Faso has been charged with crimes against humanity.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: 5 Killed at Prayer Hall; New ISIS Branch Claims Responsibility
item.description: A gunman wearing an explosives belt fired on Shiites as they took part in evening worship in the eastern city of Saihat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
